The reason being is because if you think about the centers of mass of each side, the center of mass of the handle has to be further away from the cut that we made than the sweepy part, this means that the torque at that point with the pivot point being the cut, is going to be rh * gh, where rh is the distance from the pivot point to the center of mass of the handle and gh is the gravitational force. Now, we can say the same for the torque of the sweepy bit, where the torque is rs * gs where rs is the distance from the center of mass of the sweepy bit to the pivot point. Now, since we know the torques equal out, rh * gh = rs * gs. Expanding out gh and gs, rh * mh * g = rs * ms * g, where ms and mh are the masses of the sweepy bit and handle respectively. Canceling out g on both sides, we get rh * mh = rs * ms, and since we know rh > rs, that means that in order to compensate for the difference, mh < ms. Therefore, the heavier end is the sweepy bit.
